intro: Trichinium variabile, commonly known as the variable trichinium, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped inflorescences. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory properties. Trichinium variabile is also noted for its adaptability to various soil types and its ability to thrive in moist, shaded environments.
